description.text1: A Forest Watcher é uma aplicação móvel concebida para facilitar o acesso, mesmo quando está offline, aos dados sobre as alterações na floresta recolhidos através do Global Forest Watch http://www.globalforestwatch.org/.
description.text2: O Global Forest Watch (GFW) é um sistema online dinâmico de alerta e monitorização de florestas que permite que as pessoas por todo o lado giram melhor as florestas. O GFW junta tecnologia de satélites, computação em nuvem e dados abertos para fornecer informações oportunas sobre florestas a comunidades por todo o mundo.
description.text3: A Forest Watcher coloca a informação valiosa do GFW diretamente nas mãos das pessoas que monitorizam as florestas no terreno. A Forest Watcher permite que qualquer pessoa veja alertas de fogo e desmatamento num dispositivo móvel, navegue até ao local do alerta em modo offline e recolha informações e fotografias sobre aquilo que encontra.
description.text4: Esta aplicação proporciona uma solução barata e fácil para: identificar rapidamente áreas para patrulhas de florestas ou investigações no terreno; recolher provas de alterações na floresta no terreno; usar dados recolhidos para tomas decisões de gestão e conservação baseadas em provas; e validar produtos de deteção remota no terreno.
description.text5: Especificamente, esta aplicação permite aos utilizadores:

orderList.text1: Carregar ou desenhar área(s) personalizada(s) de interesse para análise
orderList.text2: Faça o download de diversos dados sobre as alterações na área florestal, com base em imagens de satélite, e de outros dados contextuais (p. ex., alertas de desmatamento praticamente em tempo real, áreas protegidas e paisagens intactas de floresta) para qualquer dispositivo móvel.
orderList.text3: Faça o upload dos seus próprios conjuntos de dados
orderList.text4: Investigue alertas no terreno e recolha informação (incluindo pontos GPS e fotografias) através de formulários personalizáveis
orderList.text5: Rever, analisar e fazer o download de dados recolhidos com a aplicação

questions.title: O que é a Forest Watcher?

description.text: Community forest monitors, park rangers, conservation organizations, protected area managers, journalists and environmental police use Forest Watcher to detect areas of forest disturbance, inform their patrol routes and collect digital information about their observations.

questions.title: Who uses Forest Watcher?

description.text: In 2016, the Jane Goodall Institute (JGI), Global Forest Watch (GFW), Touchlab and Google partnered to create a test version of a mobile app to monitor protected areas in Uganda while offline. Following the successful pilot phase, GFW, JGI and Vizzuality created Forest Watcher to enable access to GFW data while offline and in the field. The app is currently maintained by GFW and 3 Sided Cube.

questions.title: Who created Forest Watcher?

description.text: Forest Watcher will run on any iPhone with iOS 10 and above. The minimum and recommended specifications for Android devices are listed below.

orderList.text1: Minimum specifications for Android: OS - Android 5.0; RAM - 1.5GB; Free Disk Space - 1GB
orderList.text2: Minimum specifications for Android: OS - Android 7.1' RAM - 3GB; Free Disk Space - 4GB+

questions.title: What are the device specifications for using Forest Watcher?

description.text: Yes, Forest Watcher is available in Spanish, French, Portuguese, Bahasa Indonesian, Dutch and Malagasy. The language of the questionnaires and reports can be customized to any language of your choosing.

questions.title: Is Forest Watcher available in languages other than English?

description.text1: An area of interest is an area that you define to monitor forest change within. When you create an area of interest on Forest Watcher, GLAD deforestation alerts will populate for that area.

questions.title: What is an area of interest?

description.text1: The maximum size area of interest is 20,000 square kilometers (2,000,000 hectares). If you try to establish an area larger than 20,000 square kilometers, you will receive an error message indicating the size is too big.

questions.title: What is the maximum size area of interest I can create?

description.text1: You can share areas of interest by navigating to the Areas page of the mobile app and clicking “Share Areas”. From here, you can select the areas you would like to share and choose where to export the bundle on your device. You can then share the area of interest bundle through your chosen sharing option eg. email, bluetooth or WhatsApp.
description.text2: After receiving an area of interest bundle through your preferred share option, you can import it on Forest Watcher. You can access the area(s) of interest in the Areas page once import is complete.

questions.title: How can I share and receive areas of interest?

description.text1: You can share contextual layers by navigating to the Contextual Layers section on the Settings page of the mobile app and clicking “Share”. From here, you can select the contextual layers that you would like to share and choose where to export the bundle on your device. You can then share the contextual layer bundle through your chosen sharing option eg. email, bluetooth or WhatsApp.
description.text2: After receiving a contextual layer bundle through your preferred share option, you can import it on Forest Watcher. You can access the contextual layers in the Contextual Layers section on the Settings page once import is complete.

questions.title: How can I share and receive contextual layers?

description.text: Global Forest Watch (GFW) provides preloaded forest change and contextual data on Forest Watcher. The preloaded data includes GLAD deforestation alerts, VIIRS active fire alerts, annual tree cover loss and protected areas. Information on the GLAD deforestation alerts, VIIRS active fire alerts and annual tree cover loss data is below.

content.footerText:
You can also add additional contextual layers from GFW, including LandMark indigenous and community lands, and various concessions and biodiversity data, or you can upload your own custom contextual layers through the mobile app. Forest Watcher Mobile supports the following file types for upload: .json, .geojson, .topojson, .gpx, .zip, .kmz and .kml.

When uploading additional contextual layers, you will have the option to either download the data for offline use or access the data online only. These options offer more flexibility over the data stored on your device.

For more information, please visit data.globalforestwatch.org.

orderList.text1: Alertas de Incêndio Ativo VIIRS: Produzidos pela NASA e atualizados todos os dias a uma resolução de 375 metros. Isto mostra a localização de suspeitas de incêndios na semana passada.
orderList.text2: Alertas GLAD: produzidos pelo Laboratório Global Land Analysis & Discovery (GLAD) da Universidade de Maryland e atualizados semanalmente numa resolução de 30 metros. Estes alertas mostram-lhe, semana a semana, onde pode ter havido alterações na área de floresta.
orderList.text3: Perda anual da cobertura arbórea: informação que também é produzida pelo laboratório GLAD e atualizada anualmente numa resolução de 30 metros. Estes dados revelam, de ano para ano, onde é que existiram alterações na área florestal. De momento os dados só estão disponíveis como uma camada contextual de dados: não poderá criar um relatório relacionado com um alerta de perdas anuais, embora seja possível criar um relatório para uma determinada localização se tocar, sobre o ecrã, no local onde existiram ganhos ou perdas de floresta.

questions.title: What data is available and where do they come from?

description.text1: Each data layer has been through rigorous scientific testing and has a unique set of limitations.
description.text2: Users should keep in mind that GLAD deforestation alerts detect all types of tree cover loss, whether it is caused by humans (such as logging) or natural causes (such as a landslide). The alerts do not differentiate between natural tree cover and planted tree cover. The alerts are also designed to be conservative given their intended end use of field patrols (false positive rate for confirmed alerts is 1%, while the false negative rate is 33%). Lastly, while the alerts are updated on a weekly basis, persistent cloud cover could mean that alerts are not detected for weeks or even months after the occurrence.
description.text3: VIIRS fire alerts cannot detect fires that are too small or too cool (generally smaller than 100 square meters or cooler than 700 Kelvin).
description.text4: For more information, please visit data.globalforestwatch.org.

questions.title: How accurate are deforestation and fires alerts?

description.text1: The satellite imagery basemap provided by Global Forest Watch (GFW) is updated less often than the alert data. As such, you may notice alerts for areas that still appear undisturbed on the satellite imagery basemap. To see more recent satellite imagery, we recommend you use the Recent Satellite Imagery tool available on GFW. Visiting alerts in the field is the most accurate way to verify change, but it’s also usually the most costly. Therefore, we recommend you use the Recent Satellite Imagery tool when possible before planning your field visit to identify what the likely drivers of the disturbance are.
description.text2: Alternatively, you can also upload your own satellite imagery and basemaps by navigating to the Basemaps or Contextual Layers section on the Settings page of the mobile app and clicking the + button on the top right of the page.

questions.title: Why do I see a deforestation alert but no change in the satellite imagery basemap?

description.text1: Yes, you can now upload your own contextual layers and basemaps directly into the mobile app, even while offline. You can add custom contextual layers and basemaps by navigating to either the Basemaps section or the Contextual Layers section of the Settings page and clicking the + button on the top right of the page.
description.text2: Supported file types for contextual layers include: .json, .geojson, .topojson, .gpx, .zip shapefiles, .kmz and .kml.
description.text3: Supported file types for basemaps include: .mbtiles.

questions.title: Can I upload my own contextual layers and basemaps in Forest Watcher?

description.text1: Currently, only certain types of data are synced to your Forest Watcher account, which is also connected to the Forest Watcher Web Application. This data includes areas and reports you have uploaded. This means that when you log out and log back in to the app, this data will remain visible.
description.text2: For other types of data, these are stored independently of your Forest Watcher account and will NOT be visible when you log out and log back in to the app. This data includes:

content.footerText: Logging out will permanently remove these items (with the exception of custom basemaps and custom contextual layers). It’s therefore recommended that you bundle any data that you wish to retain before logging out. For your convenience in doing this, we recommend using the ‘share all app data’ option and storing the resulting bundle. This can then be re-imported when required by opening the bundle with the Forest Watcher app when logged in.

questions.title: How does the Forest Watcher app store my data?

alertsAndData.title: Alerts and Data in Forest Watcher

description.text1: Forest Watcher Mobile allows users to create areas of interest and monitor alerts within them. Areas of interest are designated upon initiation of the app or in the Areas page. You can view the latest deforestation and fires alerts in your area of interest and download them to take offline and into the field. Once downloaded, you can use the app to guide you to nearby alerts using the phone’s internal GPS and track your route as you go, then fill out a form and take photos to record observations about what you find.
description.text2: Forest Watcher Web enables greater customization through editable reporting templates and facilitates collaboration with options to create, review and assign reports to team members.

questions.title: What can I do with Forest Watcher?

description.text: While Forest Watcher Mobile is designed primarily for offline use, certain key functions need to be performed with Internet connection. A typical workflow for Forest Watcher online/offline use is below

content.footerText: When you are offline, we recommend you put the app in “offline mode” in settings to increase the app’s stability.

orderList.text1:
Online:
Download Forest Watcher Mobile and log in.
Create an area of interest.
Set a time period for alerts and refresh alerts.
orderList.text2:
Offline:
Select and navigate to alerts.
Create a report at your location or on an alert.
Track your route.
Document observations and take photos.
Share app content with another device (alerts, areas, routes, reports, contextual layers, basemap tiles or all app content).

questions.title: What can I do online vs offline?

description.text: Forest Watcher Web is the supplementary online web interface for the mobile app, which can be used to manage areas of interest, customize report templates, configure a team of users and review and download reports submitted through the mobile app. Forest Watcher Web can be used by administrators and team managers to set up the app for their team. Users should log in to Forest Watcher Web with the same login used to access the mobile app. For more information, please visit forestwatcher.globalforestwatch.org.

questions.title: What is Forest Watcher Web?

description.text1: You can upload custom layers either Forest Watcher Web or Forest Watcher Mobile. Forest Watcher Mobile supports the following file types for upload: .json, .geojson, .topojson, .gpx, .zip, .kmz, .kml, and .mbtiles.
description.text2: Forest Watcher web supports tile URLs.
description.text3: Custom file types supported in Forest Watcher Mobile are listed below.

content.footerText: The recommended maximum file size is 1 MB, anything larger may not work properly. Complex shapes can also have issues and custom styling and images may be removed. Please contact us at forestwatcher@wri.org if you have any questions about the upload process.

orderList.text3: Google Earth Keyhole Markup Language (with .kml or .kmz file extensions)
orderList.text4: Shapefiles (with .zip extension). Shapefiles must include .shp and .prj files within the archive.
orderList.text6: Mapbox Tiles (with .mbtiles extension). These must be imported as basemaps.

questions.title: What file types and sizes does Forest Watcher accept?

description.text1: Yes, Forest Watcher Mobile is designed to be used independently from Forest Watcher Web. On the mobile app, you can create areas of interest, download and navigate to alerts, track your route along the way and record your observations. You can also upload your own contextual layers and basemaps directly through the mobile app, and share app content with other devices while offline (routes, reports, areas, alerts, contextual data layers, basemap tiles or all app content).
description.text2: Forest Watcher Web simply provides opportunities for further customization of the mobile app, including report template customization, team management and data management.

questions.title: Can I use Forest Watcher Mobile without using Forest Watcher Web?

order1.description: Se não vir quaisquer alertas na sua Área de Interesse, vá até globalforestwatch.org e verifique se existem dados para essa localização e para o período de tempo que escolheu. Se não existem alertas GLAD ou VIIRS recentes, significa que não existiu atividade recente relacionada com alterações na floresta. Considere usar a camada de dados contextuais da Alteração Anual da Cobertura Arbórea para encontrar alertas de perdas mais antigos que ainda poderão fornecer informações relevantes para uma investigação ou visita de campo.
order1.text: Não vejo nenhuns dados de alerta

order2.description: Se a aplicação falhar, abra-a novamente. Se falhar diversas vezes, por favor envie um email para mailto:forestwatcher@wri.org e inclua informação acerca do modelo do seu dispositivo juntamente com uma descrição do que estava a fazer na aplicação quando esta falhou.

order3.description: The location and navigation features rely on your device’s internal GPS. Check that the GPS (often called “location services”) is turned on in your device settings. The GPS signal can be weak indoors, so if you are inside or under a roof, try going outside. If it still doesn’t work, please email forestwatcher@wri.org telling us what device model you are using and which app version (found at the bottom of the Settings page). Cell phone GPS are usually not as accurate as standalone GPS devices, so you may also want to input the coordinates of the alert into a GPS device as backup if you have one available.
order3.text: Não consigo ver a bússola/a minha localização

order4.description: If you begin a report and then exit the report, your work thus far and the GPS coordinates of the location where your report was initiated will automatically save. You can return to your draft report later on the Reports page. You can also take a photo using your device’s camera, then upload it to a report later.
order4.text: Desejo concluir um relatório mais tarde

order5.description: When you first set up Forest Watcher, it can take anywhere from 5 to 30 minutes for the app to completely download relevant data depending on the speed of your Internet connection. If you have weak or slow Internet connection, the download will take longer. Keep the app open to allow the download to complete. After the initial set up, new alert data will download every time you connect to the Internet and the download time will vary depending on how many alerts have occurred. If you want to see if new alerts are available, pull the home screen downward to refresh.

order6.description: If you have low bandwidth, rather than redownload app content across multiple devices, you could share app content with another device while offline (alerts, areas, routes, reports, contextual layers, basemap tiles or all app content). This process will help reduce bandwidth demands.
order6.text: My team and/or I have low bandwidth

order7.description: Forest Watcher Mobile contains a lot of data and can take up significant memory on your device, depending on how many areas of interest you have, their size and the number of alerts. The fewer and smaller areas of interest you set up, the less data will need to be downloaded onto your device. We recommend having at least 1 GB of internal storage on your device so that you can use other apps in addition to Forest Watcher, though 4 GB or more is preferred.
order7.text: Fiquei sem memória no meu dispositivo

order8.description: You can use Forest Watcher Web to create a custom report template for your team to use when collecting data. You can also add notes in the final section of the form.
order8.text: I want to customize the reports that I or my team fill out when investigating an area

questions.title: Troubleshooting: What should I do if…?

description.text: We are also always looking to improve the app to meet user needs. Please contact us at forestwatcher@wri.org if there are other features that would be helpful.

questions.title: I have a great idea to improve the app. What should I do?

description.text: Entre em contacto connosco e envie as suas sugestões ou perguntas através do email mailto:forestwatcher@wri.org.

questions.title: Como é que posso obter ajuda?

description.text1: When navigating to an alert or an area, you can add a report by clicking the report button on the bottom right of the map. You will be able to take or choose pictures to add to the report, then fill out a form to record observations about what you find.
description.text2: If you begin a report and then exit the report, your work thus far and the GPS coordinates of the location where your report was initiated will automatically save. You can return to your draft report later on the Reports page. You can also take a photo using your device’s camera, then upload it to a report later.

questions.title: How do I add a report?

description.text1: To report on a group of alerts, you can click on the GLAD and/or VIIRS alerts that you’re investigating and click the report button on the bottom right of the map. You can report on multiple alerts by selecting each alert individually, before clicking the report button. When clicked on, the GLAD alerts will become green and the VIIRS alerts will become purple. The change in color indicates that the alerts have been reported on.

questions.title: How do I report on a group of alerts?

description.text1: To record a route, you can click on the start button on the bottom left of the map. Once you are done recording the route, you can click the stop button and choose whether to save the route or delete the route. If you save the route, you will then be able to access it on the Routes page of the mobile app.

questions.title: How do I record a route?

description.text1: When recording a route, points will be captured every 50 meters.

questions.title: How often does my route create points?

description.text1: You can share reports by navigating to the Reports section of the mobile app and clicking “Share Reports”. From here, you can select the reports that you would like to share and choose where to export the bundle on your device. You can then share the reports bundle through your chosen sharing option eg. email, bluetooth or WhatsApp.
description.text2: Similarly, you can share routes by navigating to the Routes section of the mobile app and clicking “Share Routes”. From here, you can select the routes that you would like to share and choose where to export the bundle on your device. You can then share the routes bundle through your chosen sharing option eg. email, bluetooth or WhatsApp.
description.text3: After receiving a reports or routes bundle through your preferred share option, you can import it on Forest Watcher. You can access the reports in the Reports section or the routes in the Routes section once import is complete.

questions.title: How can I share and receive reports and routes?

description.text1: To retrieve your reports and photos, log in to forestwatcher.globalforestwatch.org, navigate to the “Reports” tab and click “Download answers” to access your CSV file. Photos are available to download via URLs in the spreadsheet.
description.text2: Reports can also be accessed through the export function on the reports page of the mobile app. Using this function, you can download your reports directly to your device and share them with another device while offline.
description.text3: If you would like to view your data on a map, navigate to mymaps.google.com and log in to your Google account (or create one for free). Then click “Create a new map.” On the left-side panel the, click “Import” and upload your CSV from Forest Watcher Web. Select “Position of report lat” and when prompted, select “Latitude.” Select “Position of report lon” and when prompted, select “Longitude.” Select “Continue” and choose a column that you want to identify your location by. Please note that the data associated with that report will be the title attached to the blue pin(s) on the map.
description.text4: Once these steps are complete, your map will be ready and automatically save. You can click on the blue pins to see the details of your report, including photos. To change the name, click on “Untitled map” in the top left corner.

questions.title: Can I retrieve my reports and see my data on a map?

description.text1: Reports are owned by the user and are not shared publicly. For more details, visit globalforestwatch.org/terms.

questions.title: Are my reports shared or kept confidential?
